newsitem.title: COLOMBIA: Colombian Q2 GDP up 2.2 pct, down sharply from '95.
newsitem.headline: Colombian Q2 GDP up 2.2 pct, down sharply from '95.

text.p: Colombia's gross domestic product grew by 2.2 percent in the second quarter, down from a bubbling 4.7 percent growth rate in the second quarter of 1995, the National Planning Department said.
It said the economy grew 3.9 percent in the first quarter, meaning that growth during the first half of the year averaged 3.0 percent.

Finance Minister Jose Antonio Ocampo has said the government is maintaining its 4.0 percent growth target for this year. But independent analysts, including the respected economic think-tank Fedesarrollo, say real growth is expected to be closer to the 3.0 percent seen in the first half.
The 2.2 percent growth figure for the second quarter is the lowest this decade.
Loan rates of more than 40 percent have been cited as one of the leading reasons for a sharp slowdown in the industrial sector this year.
The recent appreciation of Colombia's peso currency against the dollar has also prompted growing concerns about a weakening of the country's export sector.
Political uncertainty stemming from the prolonged drug corruption scandal dogging President Ernesto Samper has been cited as another cause for Colombia's economic slowdown.
Despite the relatively poor second quarter growth figure, the Planning Department said oil output was seen growing 9.8 percent in 1996 and coal output was seen growing 20 percent.
The agricultural sector excluding coffee grew by an anemic 0.8 percent in the first half.
The Planning Department said the agricultural sector, excluding coffee, was expected to rebound to 6.0 percent growth in the second half, thanks to bumper sesame, soy, tobacco and cotton crops.
It said the calendar year's coffee crop was projected to be 8.0 percent lower than in 1995.
